title: Pie a Beta
organization: Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity Inc.
location: Student Center Quad Information Table 1 - Information Table 1
description:
Join the brothers of Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Incorporated for our “Pie a Beta” fundraiser! Stop by and take part in the fun by getting the chance to pie a brother, whipped cream, laughs, and good vibes guaranteed. It’s a lighthearted way to support our chapter while bringing the campus community together. 
   
 Can’t make it in person? No worries! Online donations are welcome, and a willing brother will gladly take a pie on your behalf. Whether you’re throwing a pie or donating from afar, your support helps us continue our community initiatives and chapter programming. Come out, have fun, and help us reach our fundraising goal!

title: Design Your Day: Discover Your Direction
description:
Not sure what to major in or where you're headed after college? Let’s change that—starting with the kind of  day  you want to have. In this hands-on, creative workshop, you’ll: 
 1) Visualize your ideal workday—where you are, who you’re with, and what you’re doing. 
 2) Identify your key work-life preferences, like flexibility, collaboration, or creativity. 
 3) Explore majors and careers that align with your vision through UC’s AI-powered  Major Mentor , a tool that matches your preferences to Montclair majors and career paths. 
 This event is open to all University College (pre-major) students. RSVP is required.  There will be complimentary food.

Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Thursday: 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Mindfulness Meditation
description:
Online. Mindfulness Meditation is the practice of being self-aware with an extra focus on your breath. Open to all who are interested in learning about meditation and developing mindfulness in daily life. Participate with video or audio only. 
 **Please note that we cannot verify attendance at this event

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: ⭐ Honor Society Info Sessions (ALD, NSCS, Tau Sigma)
description: A Prestigious Scholarship is an academic or financial award given to outstanding students for graduate programs nationally and internationally. These scholarships often come with significant financial benefits, including full or partial tuition coverage, stipends for living expenses, and sometimes additional funds for research or travel. Join us to learn more about upcoming Prestigious Scholarship opportunities for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: Journey of a Doctoral Candidate
description:
This session provides an overview of the doctoral timeline at Montclair State University, from coursework and examinations to proposal development, dissertation research, and graduation. Students will learn about key milestones, required forms, and academic expectations at each stage, as well as how The Graduate School supports doctoral progress throughout the program. Who should attend:  New and early-stage doctoral students.

title: Skills for Success: Goal Setting & Self-Motivation
description:
Ready to level up your success? Join us TODAY for our  Skills for Success: Goal Setting and Self-Motivation  workshop, where you’ll learn essential strategies to crush your goals and stay motivated along the way! What’s in store: 
 
 Tips and tricks to set achievable goals. 
 Proven strategies to stay motivated even when things get tough. 
 The chance to network and grow with other driven students like you. 
 
 This event is open to all University College (pre-major) students. RSVP is required.  There will be complimentary food.

title: 2010's DIY Nostalgia Night
description:
Throw it back to the days of glitter, bright colors, and the ultimate DIY era at 2010’s DIY Nostalgia Night! Recreate iconic favorites like Galaxy Slime, mixing shimmering glitter and bold hues for that classic space-vibe stretch. Build your own Galaxy Jar, layering dreamy colors and cotton clouds just like the crafts that once ruled YouTube. Then jump into the fun of Finger Loom Bands, making colorful bracelets just like the ones everyone traded and stacked in the early 2010s. 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Tuesday, April 7 
 7pm-9pm, must be checked in by 8:30pm to participate

title: Spring 2026 Part-time Job Fair
organization: The Office for Experiential Education and Career Connections
description:
The Spring Part-time Job Fair offers students the opportunity to meet with both on-campus and off-campus employers interested in hiring various positions. The Fair will be held in the Student Center Ballrooms from 1-3 p.m., on Wednesday, April 8.  
 
 
 More Information : 
 
 Bring plenty of copies of your resume 
 Students must bring their Montclair State University Student IDs 
 Registration is required through Handshake 
 The location is the Student Center Ballrooms 
 
 
 
 Wednesday, Apr 8, 1:00 pm - 3:00 pm 
 Student Center Ballrooms

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Preparing to Defend Your Dissertation
description: Designed for doctoral candidates approaching the final stages of their program, this session outlines the dissertation defense process from start to finish. Topics include defense eligibility, required approvals and forms, formatting and submission requirements, and final Graduate School deadlines. Students will also learn what to expect before, during, and after the defense. Who should attend:  Doctoral candidates preparing for their dissertation defense or final submission requirements. title: IDEALS, INTERESTS, AND INTERNATIONAL ENGAGEMENT: THE UNITED STATES IN WORLD AFFAIRS
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: America’s role in shaping the global political and economic order has shifted repeatedly over the last 250 years, reflecting the evolution of American interests and longstanding debates regarding the role of the United States in world affairs. Drawing on foundational principles, pivotal historical moments, and contemporary challenges, this lecture explores how American power, values, and institutions have influenced international norms, security, and governance and also how international dynamics have shaped American democracy. The lecture considers tensions between ideals and practices – democracy, markets, sovereignty, nation-building, imperialism, isolationism, intervention – in U.S. engagement abroad. Participants will be invited to reflect on the ways in which American leadership on the global stage has shaped our nation and what that implies in the current era.

title: Mindfulness Meditation
description:

 **Please note that we cannot verify attendance at this event

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: AI Literacy for Educators
description: The AI literacy for educators designed to support educators in building a strong, practical understanding of artificial intelligence in educational contexts. This workshop will help educators understand foundational AI concepts, critically evaluate AI tools and outputs, recognize how bias and inequity can emerge in AI systems, and examine the ethical and societal implications of AI use in teaching and learning. Participants will also explore strategies for working with AI responsibly, emphasizing informed decision-making and human-centered AI practice. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: AI & Ethics: Navigating Responsibility in the Age of Algorithms
description: This workshop introduces core principles of AI ethics and their implications for education, policy, and everyday use. Participants will examine case studies, identify risks, and develop strategies for responsible, equitable, and transparent AI integration. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

description: End the semester by grabbing a bag and taking crafts home for the summer. A fun, low-key way to wrap up craft nights and score some creative goodies!

description:
Dive into creativity! Make a splash with an ocean DIY craft filled with colorful sea creatures, waves, and underwater fun.  
 
 
 Take-and-Make craft kits are available for pick up at the Drop-In Center during business hours starting Wednesday, April 15th, 2026. While supplies last! FREE for students with a valid Montclair or Bloomfield campus ID. Each  craft kit comes with everything you need including acrylic paint, 2 brushes, and one ceramic sea creature. Craft kits may vary from image shown!

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: Getting Started with Canva
description: Discover the power of visual storytelling in this hands-on workshop! Learn how to create eye-catching presentations, social media graphics, and posters using Canva’s intuitive tools and templates. Perfect for students and educators looking to bring creativity and professionalism to their digital projects. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: Denim Day Decorating
description: Show your support for Denim Day with a creative twist! Join us to decorate hats and tote bags using fabric markers, patches, and other fun materials. Craft something meaningful, stylish, and entirely your own—then wear or carry it proudly. All supplies provided!

title: Denim Day 2026: Mind the Gaps, Move Forward
description:
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and together, we can break the silence.  The Montclair State University Police Department and the Office of Advocacy & Outreach are committed to fostering a campus where survivors feel heard, supported, and empowered.  It starts with believing. It starts with you.  By offering a safe and affirming response to those who disclose gender-based and sexual violence, we can create lasting change. Let’s stand together to end the cycle of silence—because  every voice matters, and every action counts. 
 Denim Day is recognized internationally as a day of action and awareness, encouraging people to wear denim to challenge victim-blaming and educate others about sexual violence.  This year, Denim Day falls on Wednesday, April 29, 2026. 
 The University Police and  Office of Advocacy & Outreach and the Office of Advocacy and Community Resilience , in partnership with over 30 campus and local community organizations, invites you to join us  from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. at the Amphitheater  for a powerful awareness event honoring survivors and increasing awareness of available resources. 
 Despite the  gaps  that still exist in the criminal justice system, in resources, and in prevention education,  we will move forward together  as a community. As part of this commitment, we will walk  one mile around campus in solidarity with survivors.

title: Canva Masterclass: Advanced Pro Tools & Design Hacks
description: Ready to level up your Canva skills? This advanced workshop dives into powerful features like animations, brand kits, collaboration tools, and interactive content creation. Go beyond the basics and learn how to streamline your design process with features like Canva’s Whiteboard for brainstorming, Website Builder for creating interactive web pages, and Presentation Mode with embedded video and transitions. Whether you're building classroom resources, school branding materials, or engaging digital content. Participants will also explore team templates, content scheduling, and how to manage brand consistency across multiple projects. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: CPT Workshop - International Students (F-1 Visa Holders) Only
description: Learn more about Curricular Practical Training (CPT) for F-1 students. Any student planning to apply for CPT is REQUIRED to attend a workshop before they can apply. This workshop is for CURRENT students ONLY - any other attendees will be removed.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: OPT Workshop - International Students (F-1 Visa Holders) Only
description: Learn more about pre-completion and post-completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) for F-1 students. Any student planning to apply for OPT is REQUIRED to attend a workshop before they can apply. This workshop is for CURRENT students ONLY - any other attendees will be removed.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.
